|1979|1983|end=divorced}} | partner = [[Goldie Hawn]] (1983–present) | children = 2, including [[Wyatt Russell]] }} '''Kurt Vogel Russell''' (born March 17, 1951) is an American actor.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/kurt-russell/161054|title=Kurt Russell News, Kurt Russell Bio and Photos|work=[[TV Guide Network]]|accessdate=June 25, 2012}} He began acting on television at the age of 12 in the [[Westerns on television|western]] series ''[[The Travels of Jaimie McPheeters (TV series)|The Travels of Jaimie McPheeters]]'' (1963–1964). In the late 1960s, he signed a ten-year contract with [[The Walt Disney Company]] where, according to [[Robert Osborne]], he became the studio's top star of the 1970s.Introduction by Robert Osborne to the [[Turner Classic Movies|TCM]] premiere of ''The Barefoot Executive'', April 13, 2007. Russell was nominated for a [[Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actor – Motion Picture]] for his performance in ''[[Silkwood]]'' (1983). In the 1980s, he starred in several films directed by [[John Carpenter]], including [[anti-hero]] roles such as army hero-turned-robber [[Snake Plissken]] in the futuristic action film ''[[Escape from New York]]'' (1981), and its sequel ''[[Escape from L.A.]]'' (1996), Antarctic helicopter pilot R.J. MacReady in the remake of the horror film ''[[The Thing (1982 film)|The Thing]]'' (1982), and truck driver Jack Burton in the dark kung-fu comedy action film ''[[Big Trouble in Little China]]'' (1986), all of which have since become [[cult film]]s. He was nominated for an [[Emmy Award]] for the television film ''[[Elvis (1979 film)|Elvis]]'' (1979), also directed by Carpenter. Russell starred in other films, including ''[[Overboard (1987 film)|Overboard]]'' (1987), ''[[Tombstone (film)|Tombstone]]'' (1993), ''[[Stargate (film)|Stargate]]'' (1994), ''[[Death Proof]]'' (2007), ''[[The Hateful Eight]]'' (2015) and ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2]]'' (2017). He joined [[The Fast and the Furious|''The Fast and the Furious'' franchise]] in 2015, having starred in ''[[Furious 7]]'' and ''[[The Fate of the Furious]]''.{{cite web|url=http://news.moviefone.com/2015/03/18/exclusive-furious-7-scene|title=This Exclusive 'Furious 7' Scene Will Really Rev Your Engine (VIDEO) |first=Drew|last=Taylor|date=March 18, 2015|work=The Moviefone Blog|accessdate=May 25, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/furious-7-cast-member-kurt-russell-reveals-plot-details-teases-eighth-movie-video-1866764|title='Furious 7' Cast Member Kurt Russell Reveals Plot Details, Teases Eighth Movie [VIDEO]|first=Tyler|last=McCarthy|date=April 1, 2015 |work=[[International Business Times]]|accessdate=May 25, 2015}} ==Early life== Born in [[Springfield, Massachusetts]], Russell is the son of actor [[Bing Russell]] (1926–2003) and dancer Louise Julia (née Crone) Russell.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/39/Kurt-Russell.html|title=Kirk Russell profile|publisher=Filmreference.com |accessdate=August 15, 2010}} He has three sisters, Jill, Jamie and Jody. Russell played little league baseball throughout his grade school years and also on his high school baseball teams. He graduated from [[Thousand Oaks High School]] in 1969.{{cite web|url=http://www.twoop.com/people/kurt_russell.html|title=Kurt Russell Timeline and Biography}} His father Bing played professional baseball. His sister, Jill, is the mother of baseball player [[Matt Franco]].{{cite web|url=https://www.si.com/vault/2002/09/02/328458/sports-beat|title=SI Vault Sports Beat|publisher=[[Sports Illustrated]]|date=September 2, 2002 |accessdate=2017-04-06}} From 1969 to 1975, Russell served in the [[California Air National Guard]], and belonged to the 146th Tactical Airlift Wing, based in [[Van Nuys, California|Van Nuys]].{{cite news |last=Libman |first=Gary |date=May 1, 1990 |title=Guard Unit Bids Farewell: The California Air National Guard turns over its Van Nuys Airport headquarters to the city of Los Angeles |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-05-01/local/me-30_1_california-air-national-guard |work=Los Angeles Times |location=Los Angeles, CA |access-date=July 27, 2018}} ==Career== ===1962–1969=== [[File:Kurt Russell Robert Vaughn Man From UNCLE 1964.JPG|thumb|Russell with [[Robert Vaughn]] in a 1964 episode of ''[[The Man from U.N.C.L.E.]]'']] Russell made his film debut for an uncredited part in [[Elvis Presley]]'s ''[[It Happened at the World's Fair]]'',[http://www.tcm.com/mediaroom/video/252072/It-Happened-at-the-World-s-Fair-Movie-Clip-Kick-Me.html "It Happened at the World's Fair -- (Movie Clip) Kick Me"]. [[Turner Classic Movies]]; retrieved August 16, 2015. and appeared in two extra episodes, celebrating the tenth anniversary of the then-defunct series ''Rin Tin Tin''.{{cn|date=May 2017}} On April 24, 1963, Russell guest starred in the ABC series ''[[Our Man Higgins]]'', starring [[Stanley Holloway]] as an English butler in an American family. He played Peter Hall in the 1963 episode "Everybody Knows You Left Me" on the [[NBC]] [[medical drama]] about [[psychiatry]] ''[[The Eleventh Hour (1962 TV series)|The Eleventh Hour]]''.{{cn|date=May 2017}} Later, he played the titular character in the ABC [[Western (genre)|western]] series ''[[The Travels of Jaimie McPheeters (TV series)|The Travels of Jaimie McPheeters]]'' (1963–64). The show was based on [[Robert Lewis Taylor]]'s eponymous novel, which [[The Travels of Jaimie McPheeters|won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction]] in 1959. In 1964, Russell guest-starred in "Nemesis", an episode of the popular ABC series ''[[The Fugitive (TV series)|The Fugitive]]'' in which, as the son of police Lt. Phillip Gerard, he is unintentionally kidnapped by his father's quarry, Doctor [[Richard Kimble]]. In [[NBC]]'s ''[[The Virginian (TV series)|The Virginian]]'', he played the mistaken orphan whose father was an outlaw played by [[Rory Calhoun]] who was still alive and recently released from prison looking for his son. Russell played a similar role as a kid named Packy Kerlin in the 1964 episode "Blue Heaven" for the western series ''[[Gunsmoke]]''. He appeared in five episodes of ''[[Daniel Boone (1964 TV series)|Daniel Boone]]'' in various roles.{{cn|date=May 2017}} At age 13, Russell played the role of Jungle Boy on an episode of [[CBS]]'s ''[[Gilligan's Island]]'', which aired on February 6, 1965.{{cite web|url=http://www.today.com/video/see-kurt-russell-as-jungle-boy-on-gilligan-s-island-915344451632|title=See Kurt Russell as ‘jungle boy’ on 'Gilligan’s Island'|accessdate=2017-04-06|work=[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]]}} He guest-starred on ABC's western ''[[The Legend of Jesse James (TV series)|The Legend of Jesse James]]''. In 1966, Russell played a 14-year-old Indian boy, Grey Smoke, adopted by the [[Texas Rangers Division|Texas Rangers]] in the episode "Meanwhile, Back at the Reservation" of the NBC western series ''[[Laredo (TV series)|Laredo]]''.{{cn|date=May 2017}} In the story line, he works for an outlaw gang, but the Rangers take him under their wing and the boy proves helpful when gunslingers try to occupy [[Laredo, Texas]].Billy Hathorn, "Roy Bean, Temple Houston, Bill Longley, Ranald Mackenzie, Buffalo Bill, Jr., and the Texas Rangers: Depictions of West Texans in Series Television, 1955 to 1967", ''[[West Texas Historical Association|West Texas Historical Review]]'', Vol. 89 (2013), p. 115 In 1966, [[Walt Disney]] wrote "Kurt Russell" on a piece of paper as his final words.White, Micah (November 26, 2013). [http://www.biography.com/news/walt-disney-biography-facts-video "Walt Disney: 7 Things You Didn't Know About the Man & the Magic"], biography.com; accessed May 6, 2017. In January 1967, Russell played Private Willie Prentiss in the episode "Willie and the Yank: The Mosby Raiders" in ''[[Walt Disney's Wonderful World of Color]]''. While filming the [[Sherman Brothers]] theatrical film musical ''[[The One and Only, Genuine, Original Family Band]]'', Russell met his future partner [[Goldie Hawn]]. Later, he, [[Jay C. Flippen]] and [[Tom Tryon]] appeared in the episode '"Charade of Justice" of the NBC western series ''[[The Road West]]'' starring [[Barry Sullivan (actor)|Barry Sullivan]]. In a March 1966 episode of CBS's ''[[Lost in Space]]'' entitled "The Challenge", he played Quano, the son of a planetary ruler and Edward's son "Whitey" in ''[[Follow Me, Boys!]]''. ===1970–1989=== [[File:Kurt Russell 1974.JPG|thumb|Russell in a 1974 publicity photo]] In 1971, he co-starred as a young robber released from jail, alongside [[James Stewart]] in ''[[Fools' Parade]]''. Later, he guest-starred in an episode of ''[[Room 222]]'' as an idealistic high school student who assumed the costumed identity of [[Paul Revere]] to warn of the dangers of pollution.{{cn|date=May 2017}} In 1966, Russell was signed to a ten-year contract with [[The Walt Disney Company]], where he became, according to [[Robert Osborne]], the "studio's top star of the '70s". Later, he starred in ''[[The One and Only, Genuine, Original Family Band]]'' and ''[[The Computer Wore Tennis Shoes]]'', the latter of which spawned two sequels: ''[[Now You See Him, Now You Don't]]'' (1972) and ''[[The Strongest Man in the World]]'' (1975).{{cn|date=May 2017}} Russell, like his father, had a baseball career. In the early 1970s, Russell was a [[Switch hitter|switch-hitting]] [[second baseman]] for the [[California Angels]] minor league affiliates, the [[Bend Rainbows]] (1971){{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=uWVYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7PcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1413%2C304473|newspaper=The Bulletin |location=Bend, Oregon|last=Anstine|first=Dennis|title=Actor to play for Hampshire|title=Russell combines acting, baseball|date=August 14, 1972|page=18}} then moved up to Class [[Double-A (baseball)|AA]] in 1973 with the [[El Paso Sun Kings#The dawn of the Sun Kings|El Paso Sun Kings]] of the [[Texas League]].{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=UVZUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UY0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6224%2C5359980|newspaper=Boca Raton News |location=Florida|last=Witbeck|first=Charles|agency=KFS|title=Bad timing|date=October 11, 1974|page=9, ''Tele-Viewer''}}{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/minors/player.cgi?id=russel001kur|title=Kurt Russell|work=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=February 18, 2011}} While in the field turning the pivot of a [[double play]] early in the season, the incoming runner at second base collided with him and tore the [[rotator cuff]] in Russell's right (throwing) shoulder. He did not return to El Paso, but was a [[designated hitter]] for the independent [[Portland Mavericks]] back in the Northwest League late in their short season. The team was owned by his father, and he had been doing promotional work for them in the interim.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=GDpYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WvcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4325%2C2505341 |newspaper=The Bulletin|location=Bend, Oregon|agency=Associated Press |title=Wise, Kurt Russell to join Mavericks for rest of season|date=July 27, 1973 |page=11}} The injury forced his retirement from baseball in 1973 and led to his return to acting.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9JhJAAAAIBAJ&sjid=coQMAAAAIBAJ&pg=1258,367525|newspaper=Youngstown Vindicator|location=Ohio|agency=Newhouse News Service |last=Freedman|first=Richard|title=Baseball player Kurt Russell banging out hits in new field |date=August 2, 1981|page=B6}} In the autumn of [[1974 in television|1974]], he appeared in the ABC series ''[[The New Land (TV series)|The New Land]]'', inspired by the [[1972 in film|1972]] [[Sweden|Swedish]] film of the [[The New Land|same name]]. Critically acclaimed, it suffered very low ratings and only aired six of the 13 episodes. In 1976, Russell appeared with [[Tim Matheson]] in the 15-episode NBC series ''[[The Quest (1976 TV series)|The Quest]]''{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} In 1980, Russell was nominated for an [[Emmy Award]] for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Limited Series or a Special for the made-for-television film ''[[Elvis (1979 film)|Elvis]]''.{{cite web|title=Nominees/Winners|url=http://www.emmys.com/awards/nominees-winners/1979 |website=Television Academy|accessdate=May 6, 2017}} During the 1980s, Russell teamed with Carpenter several times, helping create some of his best-known roles, usually as [[anti-hero]]es, including the infamous [[Snake Plissken]] of ''[[Escape from New York]]'' and its sequel, ''[[Escape from L.A.]]''. Among their collaborations was ''[[The Thing (1982 film)|The Thing]]'' (1982), based upon the short story ''[[Who Goes There?]]'' by [[John W. Campbell, Jr.]], which had been interpreted on film before, albeit loosely, in 1951's ''[[The Thing from Another World]]''. In 1986, Russell played a truck driver caught in an ancient Chinese war in ''[[Big Trouble in Little China]]'', which was a financial failure like ''The Thing'' and has since gained a cult audience. He was nominated for the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actor – Motion Picture]] for his performance in ''[[Silkwood]]'' (1983).{{cite web|url=http://www.goldenglobes.com/film/silkwood|title=Silkwood|website=Golden Globes|accessdate=March 29, 2016}} ===1990–present=== [[File:Kurt Russell.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Russell in 2005]] Russell played Lt. Stephen "Bull" McCaffrey in ''[[Backdraft (film)|Backdraft]]'' (1991), [[Wyatt Earp]] in ''[[Tombstone (film)|Tombstone]]'' (1993) and Colonel Jack O'Neil in the [[military science fiction]] film ''[[Stargate (film)|Stargate]]'' (1994). His portrayal of U.S. Olympic hockey coach [[Herb Brooks]] in the 2004 film ''[[Miracle (2004 film)|Miracle]]'', won the praise of critics. "In many ways", wrote Claudia Puig of ''[[USA Today]]'', "''Miracle'' belongs to Kurt Russell." [[Roger Ebert]] of the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' wrote, "Russell does real acting here."{{Cite web|url=https://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/miracle-2004|title=Miracle Movie Review & Film Summary (2004) {{!}} Roger Ebert|last=Ebert|first=Roger|website=www.rogerebert.com|language=en|access-date=2018-05-09}} [[Elvis Mitchell]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote, "Mr. Russell's cagey and remote performance gives ''Miracle'' its few breezes of fresh air. "{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/06/movies/film-review-a-hollywood-ending-from-real-life.html|title=FILM REVIEW; A Hollywood Ending From Real Life|last=Mitchell|first=Elvis|date=2004-02-06|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-05-09|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} In 2006, Russell claimed in one interview that [[George P. Cosmatos]] had ghost-directed the hit 1993 western film ''[[Tombstone (film)|Tombstone]]'' on Russell's behalf, saying he gave Cosmatos shot lists.Beck, Henry Cabot.{{cite web|url=http://www.truewestmagazine.com/archives/westerns/2006/western-russell_godfather_10_06.htm|title=Archived copy |accessdate=December 10, 2007|deadurl=unfit|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070122213246/http://www.truewestmagazine.com/archives/westerns/2006/western-russell_godfather_10_06.htm |archivedate=January 22, 2007}} ''True West Magazine'', October 2006; accessed May 6, 2017. Russell claimed [[Sylvester Stallone]] recommended Cosmatos to him after the removal of the first director, writer [[Kevin Jarre]], but Cosmatos had also worked with ''Tombstone'' executive producer [[Andrew G. Vajna]] before on ''[[Rambo: First Blood Part II]]''. Russell said he promised Cosmatos he would keep it a secret as long as Cosmatos was alive; Cosmatos died in April 2005. Russell said he didn’t get a chance to edit his version, but Vajna gave him a tape of "everything on the movie" and that he might try to "reconstruct the movie", although he would need to go back to the script and all his notes. Russell played the villainous Stuntman Mike in [[Quentin Tarantino]]'s segment ''[[Death Proof]]'' of the film ''[[Grindhouse (film)|Grindhouse]]''. After a remake of ''Escape from New York'' was announced, Russell was reportedly upset with [[Gerard Butler]] for playing his signature character, Snake Plissken, as he believed the character 'was quintessentially [...] American.'{{cite web|author=Stax|url=http://movies.ign.com/articles/775/775013p1.html |title=IGN: Kurt Blasts 'Escape' Remake|publisher=Movies.ign.com|date=March 22, 2007 |accessdate=August 15, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pr-inside.com/russell-enraged-with-new-snake-plissken-r75552.htm |title=News Russell Enraged with New Snake Plissken |publisher=Pr-inside.com |accessdate=August 15, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100610002318/http://www.pr-inside.com/russell-enraged-with-new-snake-plissken-r75552.htm |archivedate=June 10, 2010 |df= }} Russell appeared in ''[[The Battered Bastards of Baseball]]'', a documentary about his father and the Portland Mavericks, which debuted at the [[Sundance Film Festival]] in 2014.{{cite web|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2014/01/13/kurt-russell-sundance-baseball|title=Movie News |work=ew.com|accessdate=October 16, 2015}} He co-starred in the action thriller ''[[Furious 7]]'' in 2015.{{cite web|url=http://flicksided.com/2013/08/31/kurt-russell-joins-fast-and-furious-7-cast|title=Kurt Russell Joins 'Fast and Furious 7' Cast|work=FlickSided |accessdate=October 16, 2015}} On May 4, 2017, Russell and Goldie Hawn received stars in a double star ceremony on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] for their achievements in motion pictures, located at 6201 [[Hollywood Boulevard]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.walkoffame.com/kurt-russell|title=Kurt Russell: Hollywood Walk of Fame|website=walkoffame.com|accessdate=2017-05-06}}{{Cite California|accessdate=2017-05-06}} ==Personal life== [[File:KurtRussellSept2013TIFF.jpg|thumb|Russell at the [[2013 Toronto International Film Festival]]]] Russell married actress [[Season Hubley]], whom he met while filming ''Elvis'', in 1979, and had a son, Boston (born February 16, 1980). After his divorce from Hubley in 1983, Russell began his relationship with [[Goldie Hawn]], and appeared alongside her in ''[[The One and Only, Genuine, Original Family Band]]'', ''[[Swing Shift (film)|Swing Shift]]'' and ''[[Overboard (1987 film)|Overboard]]''. They have a son, [[Wyatt Russell]] (born July 10, 1986), and own a home in [[Palm Desert, California]].{{cite book|last1=Meeks|first1=Eric G.|title=Palm Springs Celebrity Homes: Little Tuscany, Racquet Club, Racquet Club Estates and Desert Park Estates Neighborhoods|date=2012 |page=452 (location number) |publisher=Horatio Limburger Oglethorpe|format=Kindle|asin= B00A2PXD1G}} Hawn's son and daughter with [[Bill Hudson (singer)|Bill Hudson]], actors [[Oliver Hudson]] and [[Kate Hudson]], consider Russell to be their father.{{cite web|publisher=Venus.com|title=Goldie's girl |url=http://www.ivenus.com/entertainment/films/features/TE-RW-FullLength4-KateHudson-Wk41.asp |accessdate=June 21, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051206055750/http://www.ivenus.com/entertainment/films/features/TE-RW-FullLength4-KateHudson-Wk41.asp |archivedate=December 6, 2005|deadurl=yes}} Russell is a [[Libertarianism|Libertarian]]. In 1996, he was quoted in the ''[[Toronto Sun]]'' saying: "I was brought up as a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]], but when I realized that at the end of the day there wasn't much difference between a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] and Republican, I became a Libertarian."{{cite web|title=Why Actor Kurt Russell Is a ‘Hardcore’ Libertarian - Vision Times|url=http://www.visiontimes.com/2016/01/04/why-actor-kurt-russell-is-a-hardcore-libertarian.html|website=www.visiontimes.com}} In February 2003, Russell and Hawn moved to [[Vancouver, British Columbia]], so that their son could play hockey.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/02/20/garden/at-home-with-kurt-russell-and-goldie-hawn-leather-lace-and-plenty-of-ice.html?pagewanted=all|title=At Home With: Kurt Russell and Goldie Hawn; Leather, Lace and Plenty of Ice|author=Diamond, Jamie|website=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 20, 2003}} Russell is a hunter and a staunch supporter of the [[Second Amendment to the United States Constitution|Second Amendment]] to the [[United States Constitution|U.S. Constitution]].{{cite web|title=NRA Announces New Hunters’ Leadership Forum Web Presence |url=https://www.americas1stfreedom.org/articles/2015/12/31/first-things-first/nra-announces-new-hunters-leadership-forum-web-presence/|website=www.americas1stfreedom.org|language=en}} He is also an FAA-licensed private pilot holding single/multi-engine and [[instrument rating]]s, and is an Honorary Board Member of the humanitarian aviation organization [[Wings of Hope (charity)|Wings of Hope]].{{cite web|url=http://wings-of-hope.org|title=Official Wings Of Hope Homepage|publisher=Wings-of-hope.org|accessdate=August 15, 2010}}{{cite journal|magazine=AOPA Pilot|title=A Plane Crazy America|page=79|date=May 2014}} ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !
